body:
@jihoonson 

> Well, I would say it's better to start with a stateful implementation for the supervisor even though it's not scalable. For example, the supervisor may keep all mapping information between a base dataSource and its derived dataSources in somewhere like memory, disk or metastore. Since the number of segments of a dataSource is usually several hundreds, this might not be a big overhead while the number of derived dataSources is kept small.

I thought about this mapping before. For each derived datasource, this mapping can be interval -> a list of  base segmentIds and stored in database when supervisor commit datasource metadata. However, in my experience, some dataSources have 200-400 segments and about 100-200G each day. Druid don't work well on these kinds of dataSource. We add more than 10 derived dataSources for each big dataSource to make query faster. If we keep such a big mapping for each derived dataSource,  I'm afraid that the overhead is too large. Typically, this kind of big dataSource is the best user of materialized view. However, after seeing your suggestions, I do not know which method is better now.

> Actually, the current implementation of TaskLockbox allows to use a specified segment version. 

I mean TaskLockbox doesn't have a method to set preferredVersion, instead, tasks can choose to use a specified version but not the version TaskLockbox returns. Anyway, this feature is only used when I want to control the segment version of derived dataSources in derived dataSource supervisor. Maybe it's a pseudo demand.

I have no opinion, but was just curious which types of PRs are refactoring. 
I'm merging this PR.

Depending on how you are ingesting your data you can have Druid create sharded segments. In the case of batch ingestion this is done by adjusting either `maxPartitionSize` or `numShards`. If you are using the Kafka indexing service you can tweak `taskCount` and `maxRowsPerSegment`.

However I think what you should do is just use hourly segment granularity as that will result in 7GB/24 = ~300mb segments which is pretty good.

You should post your ingestion specs so that advice can be more targeted to your use case.
It looks like it can't resolve jinzige, check that DNS is working correctly and search paths etc are properly configured.

@leventov
Do I understand correctly that there is still some concern about equals() implementation and something about build failure that I don't see how might be related to this module? Could you clarify your points regarding these please? Did I miss anything else? Thanks.

> in my experience, some dataSources have 200-400 segments and about 100-200G each day. Druid don't work well on these kinds of dataSource. We add more than 10 derived dataSources for each big dataSource to make query faster. If we keep such a big mapping for each derived dataSource, I'm afraid that the overhead is too large. Typically, this kind of big dataSource is the best user of materialized view.

That's a good point. Then, I think we need to design a fully stateless supervisor. The algorithm I suggested above is one of them. The implementation might not be such complicated even though it requires some design reviews which might take longer review cycles. 

If you have any other idea for the stateless supervisor, Please let me know.
@amalakar thanks! Would you fill CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?
Thanks for the quick review Gian, I did file the CLA. Let me know if there is anything I need to do.

> One of possible alternatives is providing an interface to tasks like adding a taskReporter to TaskToolbox. Each task can use taskReporter if they have something to report. What do you think?

Hm, I decided to keep the current implementation, since I think of the task log and the task reports as very similar things (unstructured vs. structured task logs) and felt like it would be nicer to handle the file writes/uploads together. Doing the uploads in a common place I felt was simpler than adding a file upload step to each individual task implementation.

> As a result, from the perspective of overlords, taskReport is always empty.

I felt this was fine, anything above ExecutorLifecycle in the hierarchy of runners/tasks would only see a plain TaskStatus object, so there wouldn't be an empty "taskReports" field

@josephglanville  thank you  for your timeï¼Œ when  we use it without hadoop HA, druid  can work 
when we use it wiht hadoop HA, druid throws that exception,     `hdfs://jinzige` is hadoop HA `fs.defaultFS` value,    in `hdfs-sit.xml`  content

```
  
    <property>
      <name>dfs.ha.namenodes.jinzige</name>
      <value>nn1,nn2</value>
    </property>

    ...
 <property>
      <name>dfs.namenode.http-address.jinzige.nn1</name>
      <value>amb-117:50070</value>
    </property>
    
    <property>
      <name>dfs.namenode.http-address.jinzige.nn2</name>
      <value>amb-118:50070</value>
    </property>
    
    <property>
      <name>dfs.namenode.https-address.jinzige.nn1</name>
      <value>amb-117:50470</value>
    </property>
    
    <property>
      <name>dfs.namenode.https-address.jinzige.nn2</name>
      <value>amb-118:50470</value>
</property>
```

with this configs, druid 0.10   can work ,    I'm puzzled

@jihoonson 
Could we use the current implementation before the fully stateless supervisor is well designed?  Because I believe many druid users want to use this feature as soon as fast. 
Besides, the current implementation have two extensions without any modify of core code. After we designed a stateless supervisor, it's easy to upgrade from current implementation. 
Could you please look at the pr about Materialized view implementation?
@zhangxinyu1 thanks for raising this PR! Would you add a link to the proposal here?
Oh, never mind. It's already here.
@zhangxinyu1 I think that should be documented from the first place when https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5556 is merged.
I restarted Travis. @zhangxinyu1 would you check the TeamCity inspection failure?
@jihoonson good points, I've changed this to use a TaskReportFileWriter that's injected into the toolbox
note that this configuration is not documented in the 0.12.0 docs

Saw a failure in this one:

```
testMoveSegment(io.druid.server.coordinator.CuratorDruidCoordinatorTest)  Time elapsed: 6.71 sec  <<< ERROR!
java.lang.Exception: test timed out after 5000 milliseconds
	at io.druid.server.coordinator.CuratorDruidCoordinatorTest.testMoveSegment(CuratorDruidCoordinatorTest.java:369)
```

Being optimistic, I restarted the tests. Although this test does seem potentially related to this patch.
I bet some of the paths from CliOverlord's UNSECURED_PATHS need to be added to CoordinatorJettyServerInitializer.

Hi @aubdiy,

If you run the Hadoop CLI (or some other Hadoop HDFS client) using the same classpath as Druid, does that work?

Have you tried including `dfs.nameservices` in hdfs-site.xml too?

```
<property>
 <name>dfs.nameservices</name>
 <value>jinzige</value>
</property>
```
i feel this should be assigned a milestone for 0.13.0
Sure that sounds like a good idea. Let us know if you've got time to take a look at this.
in similar vein, config for middle manager should use `druid.indexer.runner.javaOptsArray` instead of deprecated `druid.indexer.runner.javaOpts`
Thanks for the contribution @lssenthilkumar! Could you please fill out our project CLA at: http://druid.io/community/cla.html
this seems to cause coordindator to lose its leadership, even though its the only coordinator instance running

@gianm the test was added in #5528, and it also failed in a [definitely unrelated PR where i increased the timeout](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5555/commits/3a64f1fcd327ae805e3822b5cb38740cd2e3bbe9) so hopefully it will happen less often. I don't think it's because of a race condition with the curator test server used in the test because I ran it in a loop where it successfully passed ~720 times, with something like this
```
n=1; while mvn -q -Dcheckstyle.skip=true -Dpmd.skip=true -Dtest=io.druid.server.coordinator.CuratorDruidCoordinatorTest#testMoveSegment -pl server test; do echo "success: $n"; n=$[$n + 1];:; done
```
but I suppose it's possible it's still racy somewhere. Also possible is that travis just takes a bit longer than my local debug machine took to run the tests, which is why the increased timeout in the other PR.
Hey @gianm @jihoonson - Does the fix looks okay to merge?
The test passed after being restarted, so let's commit the patch.

IIRC this extra announcement was for compatibility with Tranquility. It found tasks by looking for the chat handler announcement. And the `// rofl` line was a hack to make sure the firehose is announced in the format that Tranquility is looking for. I'm not sure if it's still needed, but that would be the place to look to figure that out.

Fwiw, Tranquility these days supports a non-ZK based method of discovering tasks (it can use the overlord APIs). So we could also make that the default and then probably remove chat handler announcements completely. They were an internal thing and nothing other than Tranquility was supposed to use them. So I think it'd be ok to remove them once Tranquility's default is changed, and a new Tranquility release is done, and release notes are updated accordingly.
This is fixed by: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5554
Thank you for the report! Raised https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5563.
@drcrallen did you have any more comments on this PR?

@nishantmonu51,

The mechanism in the section "Ability to specify default values for dimensions/metrics while ingestion" is not sufficient, due to auto-detected columns. IMO, the best way to handle autodetected columns is not to ask the user to specify a default value per type, but instead to have a catch-all config like "replace missing values with defaults rather than nulls". It would be like the null handling config in the current patchsets, but only affects indexing time.

My personal opinion is that in the long run, _by default_, Druid should replace missing values with defaults at indexing time rather than storing them as nulls. But it should support nulls properly at query time if they happen to be stored in segments. (Or if an expression function returns a null from a nonnull input.)

The main reason for this is concern about the performance overhead of nullable columns. Imagine a longSum over a nonnull column vs a nullable column. The nullable one has extra work to check the bitmap, an extra branchâ€¦ it (in theory) adds up.

> The main reason for this is concern about the performance overhead of nullable columns. Imagine a longSum over a nonnull column vs a nullable column. The nullable one has extra work to check the bitmap, an extra branchâ€¦ it (in theory) adds up.

It could be handled pretty easily at query time, by checking if the null bitmap has cardinality of 0, then executing special version of code.
@gianm thank you for the review. I fixed the test failure, and updated PR title and commit message.

The test that failed, `CuratorDruidCoordinatorTest` added in #5528, is hopefully is fixed by [this commit](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5555/commits/3a64f1fcd327ae805e3822b5cb38740cd2e3bbe9) in #5555 which increases the timeout.

> I was concerned about something different: columns where there actually are nulls in the source data. If the default behavior is to store them as nulls in the columns, then this optimization isn't available, because the null bitmap will be nonempty. So my concern was that by setting the default to 'nullable' rather than 'not nullable', we will incur needless performance hits when the user doesn't really care if the missing values get stored as nulls or zeroes.

In this case, during the segment preparation phase, the default value could be written in place of null positions. Then at the query execution phase, if the query strategy is to differentiate default values from nulls, then the nullBitmap is taken into consideration, but if the strategy is to replace nulls with default values, the bitmap is just ignored: default values are "redundantly" written at all needed positions.

I think @nishantmonu51's series of patches already does exactly this in the first part (during the segment preparation phase), but no optimisations yet in the query time.

> From what I recall, get on compressed bitmaps is quite slow compared to walking an iterator.

Please make this comment in one of the patches as a review to a specific line(s) of code
Please check the CI failure.
@zhangxinyu1 thanks for the fix. I'll start my review. BTW, did you have a chance to test this feature in some real clusters?

@jihoonson Thanks! 
Yes, we have real clusters running with this feature, but the version of these clusters are 0.10.0 and this feature in our clusters is implement based on 0.10.0.  However, I have tested some functions of this implementation based on 0.13.0-SNAPSHOT in our test cluster. Do you have any suggestions about testing this feature?

I try use config in historical, it works ok.
> druid.query.groupBy.forceHashAggregation=true
@gianm @jihoonson  Also do you like the idea of combining `DruidCoordinatorConfig` and `CoordinatorDynamicConfig` ?

I saw the same issues from overlord's log via overlord console GUI page. Initially I also think this is a bug. But after survey, I found that my historical node is down as I forget to bring this node up. After historical node is up, so I can query the result from broker now and druid system behave well.

BTW, I use druid 0.12.0 which carries extension of  hadoop 2.7.3, my Hadoop cluster uses hadoop 2.9.0. 
So if this is case in your environment, pay attention to different hadoop version issue. See 
http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/other-hadoop.html

Log with stack trace
[log.txt](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/files/1871126/log.txt)
@niketh How would you suggest combining them? It isn't clear to me how it would be done, since one is updated dynamically and one is based on static configuration.

> In this case, during the segment preparation phase, the default value could be written in place of null positions. Then at the query execution phase, if the query strategy is to differentiate default values from nulls, then the nullBitmap is taken into consideration, but if the strategy is to replace nulls with default values, the bitmap is just ignored: default values are "redundantly" written at all needed positions.

It's definitely good to write default values in the "null" columns, although what I was hoping is that we could do a default configuration where:

1. Ingestion-side, we replace nulls with default values.
2. Query-side, we respect nulls if they are present in storage.

This allows the default configuration to be speedy (no nulls), while also allowing people to take advantage of more powerful null handling without too much work (they just need to change the storage-side config). Importantly, people don't need to set a cluster-wide config that changes the behavior for _all_ datasources and _all_ columns.

> Please make this comment in one of the patches as a review to a specific line(s) of code

Haha, I tried but GitHub cannot load #5278 anymore:

> This page is taking way too long to load.
>
> Sorry about that. Please try refreshing and contact us if the problem persists.

Instead, I raised an issue: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5569
Awesome. Would you mind discussing a bit about what your use case is? It sounds cool.

@gianm We have a MultiDimPartitioner which partitions on multiple dimensions. The shards are created by lexicographically sorting the n dimensions in the partitioner. We want to take advantage of getDomain to further filter segments on the broker. 
For example if we have the following dimensions a,b in our data set:
`Data: [(1,7) , (1,8), (1,9), (2,1), (2,2)] `
`ShardSpec: start: (1,7) end: (2,2)`
`GetDomain for dimension a would be (1,2)  and for dimension b would be [7, null] U [null, 2]`

These should probably be documented on the docs as you pointed out.
They are indeed passed through to the Peon.
In addition you need to set `-XX:MaxDirectMemorySize` on the Peon JVM args. i.e:
```
druid.indexer.runner.javaOpts="-server -Xmx1024M -Xms1024M -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize=320M"
```

Hi @pdeva,

It looks like this error is being thrown in some non-druid code: `io.druid.dripstat.query.datasketch.quantile.QuantilesSketchAggregator`. I'm not sure it's really a druid problem. Could you please double check that?

hmm this is weird.
so we have had our own datasketch extension we have been using since before 0.12.0, which is based on an earlier version of datasketch library. 
With 0.12.0, we add both our own extension and the druid one in the extension load list:

```
druid.extensions.loadList=["dripstat-druid-datasketches", "druid-datasketches","mysql-metadata-storage", "druid-s3-extensions", "druid-kafka-eight", "druid-kafka-indexing-service"]
```

The reason this shouldn't cause issues is because:

1. The `dripstat-druid-datasketches` would load with a different classloader (i assume) and not interfere with the `druid-datasketches`. 

2. The `type` of metric name is different for dripstat data sketches (`dsDatasketchesQuantilesSketch`) vs druid data sketches (`quantilesDoublesSketch`).

3. The middle manager node which is throwing this exception doesnt ingest the `legacy` datasource that even has the metric with the dripstat sketches library. The legacy datasource is ingested via realtime nodes.

Pasting the metrics spec for both legacy and new datasources. 

Metricsspec for datasource -`pctile-legacy`

```
"metricsSpec" : [ {
        "type": "count",
        "name": "count"
      },
        {
          "type": "dsDatasketchesQuantilesSketch",
          "name": "value",
          "fieldName": "value"
        }
      ],
```
MetricsSpec for new datasource  - `pctile-new` (using druid-datasketches):
```
"metricsSpec": [
      {
        "name": "count",
        "type": "count"
      },
      {
        "name": "value",
        "fieldName": "value",
        "type": "quantilesDoublesSketch",
        "k": 512
      }
    ],
```

The `value` metric in the new datsource refers to druid-datasketches, so not sure why its loading the dripstat datasketch library

ahh i think i found the real issue. so the previous error was because the query sent to the broker had the wrong 'type` for aggregation, referring to the dripstat sketch.

Do you have `druid.coordinator.asOverlord.enabled=true` in your config? If so, https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5579 fixes this.

HI, 

Please, share your druid config in spark. We will see what's is wrong. 
Another thing is related to your time granularity. Check your timestamp to make sure your message didn't reject by druid. 

BA.

It seems that this error is caused by the fact that first/last post-aggregations return a tuple of format
```json
...
             "postAggregatorName": {
                "lhs": 1516581790000,
                "rhs": 1
            },
...
```
where lhs is timestamp and rhs is the value you actually want. Since `finalizingFieldAccess` doesn't work with this (which I think should!), the only option I saw was using a Javascript post-aggregator (if you have it enabled), e.g.

```json
  "type": "javascript",
      "name": "extractedLastCount",
      "fieldNames": ["lastCount"],
      "function": "function(lastCount){ return lastCount.rhs; }"
    }
```

@jihoonson This seems to focus on initial data ingestion, can you comment on how this could play into things like Merge tasks? or potentially reducing the fidelity of existing data with a new index spec?

(both possibly outside the scope of MVP)

> This seems to focus on initial data ingestion, can you comment on how this could play into things like Merge tasks? or potentially reducing the fidelity of existing data with a new index spec?

@drcrallen well, this proposal is not for introducing a general parallel framework to make any task types parallelizable. Instead, it introduces new task types (and required shuffle system) for parallel indexing. Since these new task types should allow any types of splittable firehoses, they can be used for reindexing if we add a splittable `IngestSegmentFirehose`.

@jihoonson - sorry for the late reply. I have cleaned up code, removed pom changes and added an integration test. I wanted to check with you how is the integration test triggered? How is the data needed for the test loaded? I looked at existing integration tests and couldn't figure out where that magic happens.

seems like a bug in quantiles sketch module in 0.12.0 @AlexanderSaydakov 

the `DoublesSketchMergeAggregatorFactory` class is not registered in the `DoublesSketchModule.getJacksonModules()` method
ðŸ‘

Regarding the "common setup" ff you wanted to create 2 distinct tiers of historical servers you would most likely create 2 different StatefulSets, i.e `statefulset/historical-hot`, `statefulset/historical-cold` or something. Because discovery is done via Zookeeper rather than k8s labels etc no real care has to be taken when doing this, it should "just work".

We are running Druid on k8s (without Helm) so I would be interested in contributing to this effort but don't have the bandwidth to lead it right now.

As I look more into the code for this issue, the big problem seems to be tied to the fact that the firehose needs to determine how to pass an InputRow to the parser, but that can be tied to the file format (a row is stored differently in a csv than in parquet). This entanglement makes it difficult to separate the format from the firehose

I think the real sin is that InputRowParsers receive one "row" at a time, but the responsibility of splitting up a file into "rows" lies with the firehose, and it has to do that without knowing what the input file format is. At that point, what can it do other than something generic like split the file on newlines? Which is what most of the file-oriented FirehoseFactories do. And that means they won't work with Parquet files.

This design made sense for loading data from a message oriented system like Kafka, which is what FirehoseFactories were originally designed to do. It is the responsibility of the message system to deliver one row at a time. But it doesn't really make sense for reading from files, where there is the added complexity of a container format that something needs to be aware of.

I think the right design for this would be that the file-based FirehoseFactories have some additional parameter, "reader" or what have you, that knows how to split streams into rows that are acceptable to the parser. The default should be a LineOrientedReader that splits the stream on newlines into strings, but there could be another one that knows how to read Parquet files. The message-based FirehoseFactories (like Kafka) wouldn't have this parameter.

It worked on version 0.10 with some headers modification on load balancer in front of druid brokers. Load balancer is configured to add CORS headers to all responses so the cors-filter-extension is not needed.

In version 0.12 there is a new PreResponseAuthorizationCheckFilter in the end of filters chain. It checks for AuthConfig.DRUID_AUTHORIZATION_CHECKED servlet context attribute and if the attribute is not set - returns 403.

The problem is that for OPTIONS request there is no handler responsible for setting servlet attribute AuthConfig.DRUID_AUTHORIZATION_CHECKED. Even if the security is not enabled at all.

We do exactly the same, for realtime ingestion all values for high cardinality dimensions are indexed without any special handling. Observed performance degradation is minimal due to the hourly segments and short duration (current day only).

On daily basis our system builds popular values dictionary, and this dictionary is used to replace tail values from high cardinality dimensions to "Varying" during nightly batch segment re-indexing. 

It would be really nice to have tail values "normalization" for high cardinality dimensions built-in into Druid indexing tasks.
Just for reference, https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4907 should be fixed first

A big performance hit when doing what kinds of things?

Druid does have a few tools for dealing with high cardinality dimensions, I wonder if one of those would help you here.

Looks like an instance of this bug: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8157142, that's marked as a duplicate of this: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8129740, that's fixed and ported back to OpenJDK 8u121. Note that this is a `javac`, not a JVM bug; to ensure it doesn't appear again it would have been enough to update Druid binary build tooling to use a fresh version of `javac`.
